Techno-Economic Comparison of Silicon Photonics and Multimode VCSELs

who knows how long it will take, but when we got low power low latency chip to chip optical interconnects, do you still need this dense of compute? does packing denser power supply and cooling still give you higher energy efficiency? why are we still making racks? i remember a compute wall concept from some OCP presentations, i should dig it out
long term yes, in the short term the whole stack is lagging behind on how fast the compute is getting dense, like the floor to support the increasing weight of the rack..

yes, also not gonna be anytime soon in terms of just the cost of the link even with MMF. maybe some win overall as a single rack's power approaching a physical cap, not sure how much more we can get going beyond 1 MW racks.
this is what i was thinking of: [Building a Digital Twin, ASIC Emulation Platform using the OCP HPCM Wall of Compute]( https://youtube.com/watch?v=7BoEj7HwPLA)

main diff is propagation loss, fiber has effective zero until you get capped by dispersion with multimode fiber etc. Copper coax/twisted pair gives you few meters at the baud rate nvlinks are running. 100% on the hearing hazard.

when i was a middle school student, my high school neighbor told me theres this magical technology that could solve all the problems in the world and it is called calculus. I felt so good looking forward to learning it soon one day and solve all the world's problems with it.

i was doing it, i have many other complaints about macos being too protective..

"In the science package the optical and opto-electronic components are contained within a machined monolithic optical unit (black anodized Al6061). Each component is provided with a recessed pocket within the unit and is held in the pocket with epoxy (UHU 300). The SPDC photons were directly incident on the APDs without the use of collection lenses. The components most sensitive to alignment are the BBO crystal, and the two mirrors used to direct the photons to the detectors. In particular the BBO crystal had an angular tolerance at the order of± 100 μ rad." - Tang2016: [The photon pair source that survived a rocket explosion]( https://doi.org/10.1038/srep25603)

how does it feel like when an electron in a GaAs 2DEG jumps in and out of a quantum dot? Would it boast about how sketchy a trap that region was to other fellow electrons? how does it feel like when a superconducting qubit gives birth to a traveling single microwave photon that immerse itself through a TWPA? Would it get confused about all of its clones slowly appearing? how does it feel like when a high power laser pulse gets dispersed, amplified, and then compressed again? Would it leave a will to tell photons in the other beamlines this is such a worthy physical therapy session before hitting the target?
[The journey of JLF’s beamlines]( https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Y0AoJUnGFMg)

Lithium niobate still domainposturing at 30 pm/V like it’s guarding the electrothrone, meanwhile tert-butyldiphenylsilyl-armored donor–π–acceptor polymers just hyperstack-sovereign the whole modulation bloodline at 1100 pm/V   Barium titanate out here ferrocore-cosplaying with perovskite pride while bis(4-dialkylaminophenyl)phenylamino chromophores dipole-ascendancymaxx straight through the waveguide economy. Oxide veterans stuck polarization-coping with bulkbrick inertia, but these site-isolated builds are steric-throneguarding, aggregation-exiling, and voltage-throning under high-κ gatekeep tech like dielectric gravity never compiled. Crystalclingers still lattice-virtue signaling while the polymer meta is n³r₃₃-overcrowning the entire electroclout hierarchy.
what a cursed unit of nm^2/V^2 for poling curve slope - [Electro-Optic Activity in Excess of 1000 pm/V Achieved via Theory-Guided Organic Chromophore Design]( https://doi.org/10.1002/adma.202104174)

you can now freeze 20 ml of water within 2 h with elastocaloric effect, using cascaded tubular NiTi shape-memory alloy, and calcium chloride solution as the heat exchange fluid. - Zhou2026: [Sub-zero Celsius elastocaloric cooling via low-transition-temperature alloys]( https://doi.org/10.1038/s41586-025-09946-4)

interesting shape for the NiTi tubular with microfluidic channels. the compress and release cycles of the NiTi cause it to heat up and cool down, and the heat exchange fluid changes directions accordingly.
you totally can, the annoying thing is the heat exchange has to match the (potentially varying and random) pace properly to close the cycle
this is the circuit for factoring 21=3x7 ( h/t [Why haven't quantum computers factored 21 yet?]( https://algassert.com/post/2500) )
many of them "cheat", the blog article explains it quite well.
every engineered thing at a glance feel like over-engineered, and some of them are. https://x.com/grok how many transistors do i need to factor 21?

damn codex is so good at finding and grabbing arxiv papers, it's almost like it has practiced this many many times lol

expanded to 500 papers/theses and 20M tokens. it's not that many tokens.
this is a banger. many friends are trying to scale up, some with process beyond academia's wildest dreams. I'm just doing it for fun and education.
it helps me sourcing some more that I should consider getting full text. you could also traverse this graph for search & retrieval etc

never thought magna tiles are this serious. they’re secretly governed by convex polyhedral cones in a 9D parameter space. some triangles close into rings. some must coexist. some are thermodynamically illegal.
- Hübl2026: [A polyhedral structure controls programmable self-assembly]( https://doi.org/10.1038/s41567-025-03120-3)
yeah it's not that exciting, it's 2D, it's probabilistic/not consistent, and the analysis is very bruteforce

kind of, these all share the same feature of measuring extremely weak signals. most hardware for quantum stuff is still mostly classical (i.e. no need to use quantum to model how they work), just very low noise and often overpriced.
haha true these were microwave and quantum hardware engineers they got trained to be over cautious
